dc:description: The CRH gene encodes the corticotropin releasing hormone, a hormone and neuropeptide that plays a role in stress response through the hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis. CRH was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant epilepsy in 2005 (Combi et al, PMID: 16222669). Although the phenotype of the asserted gene-disease association was autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy, the curation was performed for the higher-level term, epilepsy, because the available evidence does not support an association between the CRH gene and epilepsy of any kind. All the published evidence comes from a series of studies by a single research group. CRH was initially selected as a candidate gene from within a linkage region on chromosome 8q (Combi et al 2005, PMID: 16182932). During this curation, the expert panel raised concerns about the methodology of that study, including the treatment of unaffected individuals as affected for the linkage analysis, the use of an autosomal dominant model in a pedigree with only one affected generation, and a LOD score that was statistically non-significant. All follow-up studies listed in this curation sequenced only one gene, CRH, and did not use genome-wide testing methods. Across several reports, two non-coding single nucleotide variants in the gene’s promoter region and one missense variant were identified in six families. In all six of these families, variant segregation failed to support an association of these variants with the phenotype (see curation for details). Each of the variants identified is present in population databases. Therefore, none of the published genetic-level evidence was given a score in this curation. Although experimental evidence was provided in two of the studies (Combi et al 2005, PMID: 16222669; Sansoni et al 2013, PMID: 23593457), the assays reported have no known connection to epilepsy as a phenotype, and therefore were not scored in this curation. The consensus opinion of the gene curation expert panel was that the identified variants appear to be population variants and based on current knowledge all published assertions of this gene-disease association can be refuted. In summary, the evidence supporting the relationship between CRH and autosomal dominant epilepsy has been refuted and no valid evidence remains to support the claim. New evidence would be needed to support this claim. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Epilepsy Expert Panel on the meeting date 9/21/21 (SOP Version 8).
curationReasonDescription: After review by the expert panel, all published evidence in support of this gene as a cause of epilepsy are refuted (see evidence summary), leaving the gene with essentially no valid evidence of disease association.

evidence.dc:description: As described above, the segregation information does not support the pathogenicity of either of these variants, alone or in combination. Each variant is present in population databases (e.g., gnomAD). The expert panel concluded these are population variants and the available evidence does not support their pathogenicity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Combi 2008 family

member.rdfs:label: Combi 2008 proband
member.detectionMethod: PCR sequencing of only one gene, CRH, identified as a candidate gene from previously identified linkage region.

evidence.dc:description: Several unaffected individuals were treated as affected for calculation of the LOD score, under the assumption that they were obligate carriers. This was based on the assumption of a dominant inheritance model, while the pedigree is not suggestive of dominant inheritance. The expert panel determine this LOD score calculation was not valid.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 10

member.rdfs:label: Family 10 proband
member.detectionMethod: Sequencing of only one gene, CRH, selected as candidate gene within previously-identified linkage region.
member.previousTestingDescription: Excluded linkage between this epileptic phenotype and all known brain-expressed nAChR subunit genes (CHRNA2–7, CHRNB2–4).

evidence.dc:description: Segregation does not support pathogenicity of the variant. Each parent of the proband is heterozygous for the variant, though only the father is affected. Two siblings of the proband are homozygous for the variant, but appear to have the same phenotype as the heterozygous proband. The expert panel concluded this segregation does not support pathogenicity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 7

evidence.dc:description: The segregation information in this family, described above, does not support scoring this family.
evidence.rdfs:label: Sansoni 2013 familly

member.rdfs:label: Sansoni 2013 proband
member.detectionMethod: PCR sequencing of a single gene, CRH

evidence.dc:description: Segregation in the family does not support pathogenicity. Identification of the variant was based on selective sequencing of one gene only. The variant is a common variant in population databases with an allele frequency ~4%. The expert panel concluded this is a population variant and the available evidence does not support pathogenicity.

Identification of the variant was based on selective sequencing of one gene only. There is no segregation data for this family. The variant is a common variant in population databases with an allele frequency ~4%. The expert panel concluded this is a population variant and the available evidence does not support pathogenicity.

Segregation information in this family do not support pathogenicity. The variant is present with multiple observations in the gnomAD population database, and is classified as Likely Benign in ClinVar. The expert panel concluded this is a population variant and the available evidence does not support pathogenicity.

Identification of the variant was based on selective sequencing of one gene only. There is no segregation data for this family. The variant is a present with multiple observations in population databases (gnomAD). The expert panel concluded this is a population variant and the available evidence does not support pathogenicity.
